pr_title: ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

timeline.message:
ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

* Avoid new byte[] instance when reading cache name
* Improve parsing and matching of media types
* Simplify copying of collections
* Avoid new array instance in withFlags(Flag)
* Avoid new lambda instance when stage is completed successfully
* Use HopscotchHashMap for GlobalMarshaller primitive ids
* Simplify ExtendedByteBufJava.readMaybeVInt() logic
* Call withFlags() only once in HotRodHeader.getOptimizedCache()
* Don't include key media type parameters in knownCaches key in
  RestCacheManager.getCache()

ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

* Avoid new byte[] instance when reading cache name
* Improve parsing and matching of media types
* Simplify copying of collections
* Avoid new array instance in withFlags(Flag)
* Avoid new lambda instance when stage is completed successfully
* Use HopscotchHashMap for GlobalMarshaller primitive ids
* Simplify ExtendedByteBufJava.readMaybeVInt() logic
* Call withFlags() only once in HotRodHeader.getOptimizedCache()
* Don't include key media type parameters in knownCaches key in
  RestCacheManager.getCache()

ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

* Allow space and tab between media type subtype and parameters
* Don't allow spaces between type and subtype,
  or between parameter name and parameter value

ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

* Allow space and tab between media type subtype and parameters
* Don't allow spaces between type and subtype,
  or between parameter name and parameter value
* Unescape and remove quotes from quoted parameter values

ISPN-11005 HotRod decoder small performance improvements

* Do not remove quotes or backlashes from quoted parameter values

timeline.bodyText: Is this faster than the current code on master?
timeline.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I haven't ran any performance test after adding the regular expressions, but I expect it to be faster because it goes over the input string only one time and it does fewer allocations: the code on master allocates new strings with substring(), split(), and toCharArray().
But it shouldn't matter for performance IMO, as most performance-sensitive applications should be using the id of application/x-protostream instead of a textual media type. The regex change was motivated mostly by the fact that I wanted something that follows the RFCs as close as possible, and I found an answer on StackOverflow doing it with regular expressions :)
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
Parsing of MediaType does impact performance, as every REST call will send a text for every request.
If the regex make it slower, I don't think the extra complexity is worth it.
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
The regex change was motivated mostly by the fact that I wanted something that follows the RFCs as close as possible

Understood, but this PR is for small performance improvements, and if we don't know if it will improve, I suggest separating the MediaType changes to another JIRA
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
You were right @gustavonalle, I wrote a JMH benchmark and the regular expression parsing was a bit slower than master:

Benchmark
Mode
Cnt
Score
Error
Units




master
MediaTypeParsingBenchmark.State.parseList
avgt
30
38.041
± 0.299
ns/op


ISPN-11005
MediaTypeParsingBenchmark.State.parseList
avgt
30
56.855
± 0.492
ns/op



I was able to make it faster (although a bit uglier because I had to expand the character ranges), but then I realized it's too big a change and it needs its own PR. I only left the matchesAll field that speeds up comparisons in this PR.
replies.author: danberindei
